crooked forest is the result of heavy snowfall flattening the supple tops of the trees every year for months at a time, then spring growth, then another winter folding the top in a continuous direction around the trunk in the first few years of its life. Kind of like the wind blown trees on seaside cliffs would be if the winds stopped for a season then started again would result in zig zag sections.

I am very disappointed with the last entry of the list, with the woman describing the source of the blue flames as 'lava'. it isn't. Lava is molten rock, rock being made of minerals which are themselves made of chemical elements.  The liquid that is burning to produce the blue flames is molten sulfur, a single chemical element, so therefore not a rock and not lava. The vents of Kawah Ijen are spewing out volcanic gases, including elemental sulfur in vapour form. It's cooling and condensing ( helped along by humans who have hammered pipes into the vents to speed up the cooling and solidifying of the sulfur), so you literally get flows of molten sulfur running down the crater walls. The flows still produce some vapour and it's this reacting with oxygen to create the blue flames. Please, please, PLEASE  double and triple check the facts before releasing videos- especially  these types of science videos which people tend to  use as references later on!

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I was told by a doctor that I have very dry skin compared to most people.
I knew water was required for sulfuric acid to do what it does.
I bought concentrated sulfuric acid and placed 1 drop on my arm. While I never received any burns, nor felt any discomfort on my arm during the 2 minute exposure, moisture in the air and my eyes forced me to end the experiment.
My eyes started to water and burn, and I could tell heat was starting to build at the test spot.
To this day, no hair grows in that small spot.
Over-all, it was not actually an experiment to test acidity.
It was however, an experiment in an attempt to disprove the doctor. Results proved him to be correct.

16:14....this is NOT the cambiun, this is heart/sap wood. The cambium, or cork cambium is the layer between the "wood" and the "bark", the living cambium serves as a circulatory system feeding sugar produced in leaves down to the roots for use and storage as needed. This layer is replaced every year, with the new layer forming between the old cambium and the sap wood, thus pushing the old cork cambium out, which because the tree is now a larger diameter, causes the cork cambium to crack into sections, which when built up over time creates what we call "bark". Therefore, bark is nothing more than old layers of cambium, which has since died, and now serves as a protective layer.

I have a bunch of little jade plants that are cuttings from a single, 85yo plant. I was bestowed with this family heirloom in the same pot it’s been in for those entire 85 years, so it had root rot and was slowly dying. Kawah Ijen doesn't currently erupt lava. It is only releasing gases, some of which, like the video said, are sulfur compounds. Entrepreneurial daredevils living nearby saw that the sulfur gases reacted together to form elemental sulfur (a useful element in the production of sugar, of all things), and so they installed metal condensing pipes into the volcano's fumaroles (gas vents) to cool the gases before they are released to the atmosphere, resulting in more yellow stuff to mine, and more money in their pockets (though it's a very dangerous job and certainly shortens life spans to under 40 years for people who do it long enough - these gases are quite toxic). When the sulfur burns, it glows blue. But it is decidedly not lava, there is no glowing, Hawaiian-style molten rock coming out of that volcano. In fact, the volcano hasn't actually erupted AT ALL for about 15 years. Please get your facts straight SciShow.

On another note, Ol Doinyo Lengai volcano in Tanzania could have easily made the list as a volcano that looks really weird, and does really weird things (lava flowing nearly as fast as water, for one, plus it makes some very bizarre-looking landforms). You could actually make a whole video about odd volcanoes on Earth and throughout the Solar System; though most volcanoes fall pretty definitively in a category that contains hundreds of other examples, there are plenty of volcanoes that are in a league of their own, so to speak.

@20:16 The video claims that the pH of the lake is stronger than the acid in a car battery. This does not sound right and it is not right.

The concentration of sulfuric acid in a lead battery can be around 4 to 5 mol/L when fully charged, but it decrease as the battery is discharged.

The definition of pH is:

pH = -log(conc. of H+)

To calculate pH in this case we can safely assume that the first deprotonation is complete and the second deprotonation is negligible.

We thus get (we ignore that the calculated pH is probably not accurate as we are not dealing with a diluted solution):

pH = -log(4) = -0.6 or pH = -log(5) = -0.7

Note that it is not an error to have a negative pH, nor is it an error to have pH above 14.
